abstract: A day after the nation was given a negative credit outlook, President Obama and Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner tried to reassure investors.
snippet: A day after the nation was given a negative credit outlook, President Obama and Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner tried to reassure investors.
lead_paragraph: Stocks on Wall Street rose on Tuesday as investors focused on corporate earnings and the economy, moving on from the negative credit rating outlook given to the United States the previous day.

headline.main: Administration Defends Effort on Debt After Credit Warning
headline.print_headline: Shaking Off S.&P. View, Shares Rise on Earnings and Housing

abstract: In a CNBC interview, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner sought to assuage concerns about the possibility of a political impasse over federal restrictions on debt levels, which Standard & Poor’s recently said could lead to defaults.
snippet: In a CNBC interview, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner sought to assuage concerns about the possibility of a political impasse over federal restrictions on debt levels, which Standard & Poor’s recently said could lead to defaults.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner parses comments in a report issued by Standard & Poor’s, which called for a ratings cut for the United States over concerns about sovereign debt. Mr. Geithner disagreed with the finding, saying that there was “no negative outlook” for the economy. In a video interview on CNBC, he sought to assuage concerns about the possibility of a political impasse over current federal restrictions on debt levels, which S.&P. said could lead to defaults.
